segment.source: Sometimes a server hosts data that is sensitive.
segment.target: Sometimes a server hosts data that is sensitive.

segment.source: If your servers host data that must not be compromised, you have several options to help protect that data.
segment.target: If your servers host data that must not be compromised, you have several options to help protect that data.

segment.source: One was already addressed: adding the server to the encryption zone.
segment.target: One was already addressed: adding the server to the encryption zone.

segment.source: Membership in that zone prevents the server from being accessed by any devices that are outside the isolated domain, and encrypts all network connections to server.
segment.target: Membership in that zone prevents the server from being accessed by any devices that are outside the isolated domain, and encrypts all network connections to server.

segment.source: The second option is to additionally restrict access to the server, not just to members of the isolated domain, but to only those users or devices who have business reasons to access the resources on the server.
segment.target: The second option is to additionally restrict access to the server, not just to members of the isolated domain, but to only those users or devices who have business reasons to access the resources on the server.

segment.source: You can specify only approved users, or you can additionally specify that the approved users can only access the server from approved devices.
segment.target: You can specify only approved users, or you can additionally specify that the approved users can only access the server from approved devices.

segment.source: To grant access, you add the approved user and device accounts to network access groups (NAGs) that are referenced in a firewall rule on this server.
segment.target: To grant access, you add the approved user and device accounts to network access groups (NAGs) that are referenced in a firewall rule on this server.

segment.source: When the user sends a request to the server, the standard domain isolation rules are invoked.
segment.target: When the user sends a request to the server, the standard domain isolation rules are invoked.

segment.source: This causes IKE to use Kerberos V5 to exchange credentials with the server.
segment.target: This causes IKE to use Kerberos V5 to exchange credentials with the server.

segment.source: The additional firewall rule on the server causes Windows to check the provided device and user accounts for group membership in the NAGs.
segment.target: The additional firewall rule on the server causes Windows to check the provided device and user accounts for group membership in the NAGs.

segment.source: If either the user or device is not a member of a required NAG then the network connection is refused.
segment.target: If either the user or device is not a member of a required NAG then the network connection is refused.

segment.source: Isolated domains and isolated servers
segment.target: Isolated domains and isolated servers

segment.source: If you are using an isolated domain, the client devices already have the IPsec rules to enable them to authenticate traffic when the server requires it.
segment.target: If you are using an isolated domain, the client devices already have the IPsec rules to enable them to authenticate traffic when the server requires it.

segment.source: If you add an isolated server, it must have a GPO applied to its group with the appropriate connection security and firewall rules.
segment.target: If you add an isolated server, it must have a GPO applied to its group with the appropriate connection security and firewall rules.

segment.source: The rules enforce authentication and restrict access to only connections that are authenticated as coming from an authorized device or user.
segment.target: The rules enforce authentication and restrict access to only connections that are authenticated as coming from an authorized device or user.

segment.source: If you are not using an isolated domain, but still want to isolate a server that uses IPsec, you must configure the client devices that you want to access the server to use the appropriate IPsec rules.
segment.target: If you are not using an isolated domain, but still want to isolate a server that uses IPsec, you must configure the client devices that you want to access the server to use the appropriate IPsec rules.

segment.source: If the client devices are members of an Active Directory domain, you can still use Group Policy to configure the clients.
segment.target: If the client devices are members of an Active Directory domain, you can still use Group Policy to configure the clients.

segment.source: Instead of applying the GPO to the whole domain, you apply the GPO to only members of the NAG.
segment.target: Instead of applying the GPO to the whole domain, you apply the GPO to only members of the NAG.

segment.source: Creating multiple isolated server zones
segment.target: Creating multiple isolated server zones

segment.source: Each set of servers that must be accessed by different sets of users should be set up in its own isolated server zone.
segment.target: Each set of servers that must be accessed by different sets of users should be set up in its own isolated server zone.

segment.source: After one set of GPOs for one isolated server zone has been successfully created and verified, you can copy the GPOs to a new set.
segment.target: After one set of GPOs for one isolated server zone has been successfully created and verified, you can copy the GPOs to a new set.

segment.source: You must change the GPO names to reflect the new zone, the name and membership of the isolated server zone group to which the GPOs are applied, and the names and membership of the NAG groups that determine which clients can access the servers in the isolated server zone.
segment.target: You must change the GPO names to reflect the new zone, the name and membership of the isolated server zone group to which the GPOs are applied, and the names and membership of the NAG groups that determine which clients can access the servers in the isolated server zone.

segment.source: Authentication methods.
segment.target: Authentication methods.

segment.source: Include at least device-based Kerberos V5 authentication for compatibility with the rest of the isolated domain.
segment.target: Include at least device-based Kerberos V5 authentication for compatibility with the rest of the isolated domain.

segment.source: If you want to restrict access to specific user accounts, also include user-based Kerberos V5 authentication as an optional authentication method.
segment.target: If you want to restrict access to specific user accounts, also include user-based Kerberos V5 authentication as an optional authentication method.

segment.source: Do not make the user-based authentication method mandatory, or else devices that cannot use AuthIP instead of IKE, including Windows XP and Windows Server 2003, cannot communicate.
segment.target: Do not make the user-based authentication method mandatory, or else devices that cannot use AuthIP instead of IKE, including Windows XP and Windows Server 2003, cannot communicate.

segment.source: Likewise, if any of your domain isolation members cannot use Kerberos V5, include certificate-based authentication as an optional authentication method.
segment.target: Likewise, if any of your domain isolation members cannot use Kerberos V5, include certificate-based authentication as an optional authentication method.
